data.question: In the novel the 'pad' was a symbol of
data.section: Questions 21 - 30 are based on Chukwuemeka Ike's The Potter's Wheel
data.solution:
Pad was a symbol of failure. Whoever fails during the previous year's annual examination was required to carry pad on his head throughout the first week of the new school year.

See page 117

option.c: they are very close to each other

data.solution: This means to be too close to someone or spend too much time with someone.

data.question: As the drama unfolded, Olatinuke was advised to keep her shirt on

option.a: she was advised to commit herself
option.b: she was advised to stay calm
option.c: she was advised to join the club
option.d: she was advised to wear her shirt

data.section: questions 36 - 45 are on LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of this question select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence.
data.solution: She was advised to exercise self control, control her emotions/anger,  to stay calm.

data.question: He is a clinging child.

option.b: he likes to cling with his sister.
option.d: he is a handsome young man

data.section: questions 36 - 45 are on LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of this question select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence.
data.solution:
clinging; means to hold on or be attached to someone or something. 

''He is possessive'' is the correct answer.

data.question: Zinana's examination result was not unfavourable

option.a: Her examination did not meet expectation
option.b: she was successful in her examination
option.c: her result could not earn her admission

data.section: questions 36 - 45 are on LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of this question select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence.
data.solution: Her exam was good, it was favourable, it met expectations.

data.solution: This means, you need to get better or improve at speaking Spanish

data.solution: The new bride is looking forward to motherhood.

option.a: She expressed it secretly and courageously
option.b: she expressed it quietly and cautiously
option.c: She expressed it feebly and sickly
option.d: She expressed it clearly and strongly

data.section: questions 36 - 45 are on LEXIS, STRUCTURE AND ORAL FORMS In each of this question select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence.
data.solution:
Feebly; in a way that fails to convince or impress.

Not feeling sure about what to do

data.question: Chibuzor gave a <u>curt</u> nod and walked away
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: curt;  rudely brief.

data.question: The girl took a <u>cursory</u> glance at the letter and hid it
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: cursory; hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.

data.question: The relationship between the couple has been <u>frosty</u>
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
rosty; cold and unfriendly in manner.

Cordial; warm and friendly

data.question: The Novel laureate's activity in the field of science is <u>heinous</u>
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
Heinous; (of a person or wrongful act, especially a crime) utterly odious or wicked.

Laudable; (of an action, idea, or aim) deserving praise and commendation.

data.question: The accused was <u>eventually</u> convicted
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
Eventually; in the end, especially after a long delay, dispute, or series of problems.

Initially; means at first

data.question: The <u>plebs</u> can be found in every society of the world
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
plebs; an ordinary person, especially one from the lower social classes.

Elite; a select group that is superior in terms of ability or qualities to the rest of a group or society.

data.question: Everyone's condition was <u>appalling</u>
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: Appalling; very bad; awful.

data.question: The war against malaria keeps <u>waxing</u>
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: waxing; to grow larger or stronger.

data.question: The man's <u>mordant</u> wit is apparent to the entire village
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
Mordant;  having or showing a sharp or critical quality; to be bitter or caustic,

kind;showing empathy

data.question: The soldiers tried in their <u>dogged</u> defence of the city
data.section: In each of questions 46 to 55, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
Dogged; is being relentless, purposeful, persistent and not giving up easily. 

Indifferent; having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.

data.question: Ayodeji is an <u>ardent</u> support of education for the girl child
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: Ardent; very enthusiastic or passionate.

data.question: The scholar's <u>epitaph</u> was demolished
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
Epitaph; a phrase or form of words written in memory of a person who has died, especially as an inscription on a tombstone.

Monument; is a statue or other structure placed over a grave in memory of the dead.

data.question: Mohammed does his work with so much <u>ardour</u>
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: Ardour; great enthusiasm or passion.

data.question: The athlete is proud to be in the <u>vanguard</u> of sports development
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: If someone is in the vanguard of something, they are involved in the most advanced part of it. It simply means, "front guard''

data.question: Nwankwo was on the <u>verge</u> of signing a two year contract with the club
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
Verge; To be at the extreme end or edge of something.

Brink; the extreme edge of something happening

data.question: The lamb is a <u>feeble</u> little animal
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: Feeble; in this context means, lacking physical strength. Being weak

data.question: I am tired of your <u>eternal</u> argument
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: Eternal; lasting or existing forever; without end. Endless, constant

data.question: The actress <u>screamed</u> when she noticed an object behind her
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
scream; to give a long, loud, piercing cry or cries expressing extreme emotion or pain.

Wail; make a prolonged high-pitched sound or cry

data.question: The <u>exhibition</u> was an eye opener to all
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution: Exhibition; a public display of works of art or items of interest, held in an art gallery or museum or at a trade fair.

data.question: As a journalist, Bala has always had a <u>nose</u> for stories
data.section: In each of questions 56 to 65, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase underlined.
data.solution:
In this context, to have a nose is to have the ability to sense or find something, such as news, trouble, gossip, etc.

Example; She really has a nose for news. She's a good reporter.

data.question: The girl says she is averse.....what others admire
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: 'To'' as an adverb is used here to connect the relationship the speaker and the subject

data.question: Our teacher defined ......in his introductory lesson
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution:
The correct option is option A.
Onomatopoeia; is the formation of a word from a sound associated with what is named. Example animals sounds such as meow, chirp etc

data.question: The philanthropist devoted himself......the poor
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution:
The philanthropist devoted himself to helping the poor.

This means that the philanthropist have dedicated himself to a course. The verb ''helping'' means that, the act is in present continuous tense.

data.question: Tinu likes apples......she does not like oranges
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution:
But; is used to introduce a phrase or clause contrasting with what has already been mentioned.

Tinu likes apples but she does not like oranges.

The second phrase contradicts what was already said.

data.question: The students had a .....On Independence Day.
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: march past; simply means a parade or procession

data.question: Do you mind......another hour or two?
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution:
Do you mind waiting another hour or two?

The construction waiting represents the future progressive of the verb wait

data.question: The continuous rain has really .......the soil.
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: Saturated means to be thoroughly soaked. Or holding as much water or moisture as can be absorbed

data.question: The police described the boy as being.....hand
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: Out of hand means to be out of control.

data.question: It was very easy for the two political parties to form a .......Government
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution:
It was very easy for the two political parties to form a coalition Government,

A coalition government is a government formed jointly by more than one political party.

data.question: All farmers were encouraged ......carry out fumigation on their farms
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: All farmers were encouraged to carry out fumigation on their farms

data.question: Yours is to command.....is to obey
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution:
Theirs is a personal pronoun, used to modify a noun in order to indicate possession but with greater emphasis on identity of possession.

Example; Those books are theirs.

data.question: Local governments are authorized to pass
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: A bye law is a regulation made by a local authority or corporation. Since the Subject of the noun is in plural form, the laws will also be in plural.

data.question:
Umar: I have never visted the dentist
Aliyu: ......?
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: Neither have I; is used to say that a negative sentence is also true for me.

data.question: Usman would have won the race.....

option.a: only if he could run fast

data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: Run is the past participle form of the irregular verb run. Ran is the simple past form of the verb. With the auxiliary verb had you are using the past perfect tense. We use the past participle form of the main verb combined with the auxiliary verb in this tense. So, had run is the correct choice

data.question: My father told me to take the money from .....it
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: In formal speech or writing, "whomever" is the form of "whoever" used when it is the object of a verb or preposition. In this case, it is not the subject of the verb hence ''whoever offers'' is the correct option.

data.question: Our teacher defined.......as the killing of one's mother
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: Matricide is the killing of one's mother.

data.question: If you are confused.......anything, phone my office
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution:
About is correct.
"Confused with", is generally used when you fail to distinguish or mistake one for an other. For example, 'I always confuse Tanya with her sister'.
On the other hand, "Confused about" is used when 'confuse' is given it's literal meaning. For example, "I am confused about what to do with this degree that I've got".

data.question: We have a family mutiny......our hands
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: The preposition ''on'' correctly fills in the gap, When you say you have a mutiny on your hands, it means you have a case of rebellion at hand that needs to be attended to.

data.question: We should try to help.....
data.section: In each of question 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap (s)
data.solution: The less fortunate is grammatically correct. When we say ' the less fortunate,' we generally mean the poor rather. ie, we are referring to people in a group.
